ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .

The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Lei Zhao  Lei Zhao
Instructor: Lei Zhao  Lei was very helpful and attentive.
Instructor: Molly R. Roske  Molly was a great help to me and a very good educator!
Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  Natalie Schultz
Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  Natalie was a superb TA.
Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  Natalie was great, very knowledgeable and helpful in lab.
Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  She is wonderful
Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  Natalie was amazing!!!!! whether by email or in person, she never made me feel incompetent for asking questions and she was always there to help out! She was great!
Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  Natalie was great. She helped me a lot.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I thought the pace of the class was off: lots of problem sets and dense lectures frontloaded, then the midterm pretty early too. The second half of the course seemed to tail off when lectures weren't as obviously critical to attend unless they related to one's final project. I think it would have been interesting to spread the topical lectures throughout the term rather than just have them all at the end (at least the ones that lend themselves to that change), and to delay the midterm or spread the problem sets out as well.

I had trouble grasping the concepts in the first half of the class. I think that overall more lab time and less class time would have been really beneficial. Im not sure how you can better communicate the theortically concepts, but I think discussing them while working on the computer would help me make the connection. The labs are where I learned the most and Larry was a great help during labs and while developing my final project.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Individual help from Larry and the TAs in the lab was amazing!

This class was extremely well thought out. The labs and lectures were synced to reinforce concepts. I felt like I learned so much both re: physics of remote sensing and technique. I haven't been this excited about a class in a long time--my favorite of the semester, certainly.

The final project of the course provides some excellent depth to the class and lets you apply techniques learned in labs. Guest lectures provide some great examples of how RS techniques are applied in research.
The labs are excellent. The project course timeline could be adjusted and the aims made more specific.
The labs really solidified the material and skills.
labs and project
Labs!

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The pace of the class, as described above, and helping students gain a sense of "purpose" to the labs aside from just working through a step-by-step guide. I felt like it was easy to disengage from what I was doing if it didn't feel like I was in search of the answer to a particular question.

I liked the organization and approach of this course. I am not sure I have an substantive feedback. The timing between the second problem set and the exam were a bit tight. I also wish we received feedback on labs a bit sooner (it would have been helpful for final project to make sure we weren't completely off in our thinking). That said, there was so much support in the lab from Larry that he made sure you were on track.

Lectures later in the semester were interesting to attend but felt optional.If you want to continue with RS work after the class, you basically have to either integrate it into an independent research project or have the timing right to catch Seto's advanced class, taught every other year--not in the cards for me.
Final Project. The final paper could be defined a little better.
One less lab at the end so there's more time to work on the final project.
More time in lab, explanation of the theoretical concepts of remote sensing.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: See Question 17.

Very closely related. They both reinforced each other well. I sometimes would do the labs before the relevant lecture, which personally, was more helpful. I went into lecture with relevant questions and more engaged in material.
Labs utilized the course material or guest lectures for the given week.
Yes, they directly related, and the labs used the lectures for that week. I thought this course had one of the most integrated lecture/lab combinations.
Yes, labs aligned with lecture content. It was helpful to refer to the labs when we began working on our final projects.
More lab time would have helped improve this relationship

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Lei Zhao  Teaching assistant was very helpful. I often did labs outside of assigned time though, so my interactions were limited.
Instructor: Lei Zhao  Extremely helpful and explained complicated material clearly. Also very approachable. Lei is the best.
Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  Natalie was incredibly helpful and friendly. I don't see a clear place for improvement!
Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  Natalie was great. The only critique I can offer is maybe to offer more comments on the initial project proposal.
Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  Natalie was great! No improvements needed

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am interested in using remote sensing for research. I would love to take the advanced course as well, but it seem Karen Seto is on sabbatical next year...
I took the course with the goal of obtaining a new, practical skill. I think the course was effective in that regard.

I am interested in tools that detect environmental impacts at the landscape level, as well as the macro level. But also, remote sensing provides the data used in GIS, and I think it's important to start with the foundations.
very helpful tool
I will be using remote sensing in my summer field work so this fits in directly with this. It is a very useful tool in the field of conservation and Im excited to learn more and apply it directly.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I've been looking forward to learning more about other tools to assessing landscapes.
Interest in remote sensing. I attended a Friday Google Earth session and Larry advertised the course during that meeting.
Most of the questions I am interested in are at the larger scale and benefit from spatial analysis.
Part of my course of study. Important to future career work.
see above. Also, Professor Lee is a great instructor.
to build on my gis remote sensing skills from college
Needed it for my fieldwork

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes!
Exceeded my expectations. It was a great course.

Generally yes--I left with a good understanding of the basics of ENVI but would have liked to have at least been introduced to some more advanced techniques. However, the ENVI software package is expensive and has less of a distribution than more common (and functionally different) programs like ArcGIS--I am not sure how likely I am to encounter it in non-academic environments.
Yes
Yes and exceeded them. I didn't knowmuch about remote sensing, and the course introduced me to additional possibilities. It's a rich field, and I'd like to continue with it next year.
would like to explore deeper and use the tool more often
Yes! I feel comfortable doing the basics of remote sensing.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I worked on labs together with other students. This was helpful for discussing concepts and ensuring we knew what ENVI was doing (or when it was misbehaving)!

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take it! Even if remote sensing is only tangentially related to your work, this course will provide a basic understanding of a field of growing importance.

The first week of the course is not representative of the rest of the class. Actually, the class is more like 2 courses in one--the first part is closer to an undergraduate class, with physics problem sets and memorization of terms. The second half is more conceptual and focus turns to work on your final project. Beyond the first 2 weeks I didn't find readings necessary to grasp the material--generally most learning at this point was done in labs.
Pay attention to the two problem sets and all the labs - they're really fundamental exercises, and you'll be thankful when it comes to the end of the course.
Engage in the labs! This is where you will learn the most. Somedays I was tired and just followed the instructions, but I got the most when I was trying to understand why I was doing what I was doing
